questions.text: 1. A 21-year-old female presents with amnesia for an event that occurred 2 weeks ago (the death of her father in an RTA, which she witnessed). She reports having flashbacks of the event repeatedly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Acute stress disorder.

Acute stress disorder is characterised by a relationship between an exceptional stressor (such as the death of a loved one, natural catastrophe, accident, or rape) and the onset of symptoms. It is characterised by the development of transient emotional, somatic, cognitive, or behavioural symptoms as a result of exposure to an extremely threatening or horrific nature. 

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and acute stress disorder both present with the same set of symptoms:

* Intrusive symptoms such as recurrent nightmares and flashbacks of the event, psychological distress due to stimuli that are reminders of prior trauma

* Avoidance of external reminders of trauma

* Negative mood or cognition related to the trauma

* Altered level of arousal, such as sleep disturbances and hypervigilance

A diagnosis of PTSD is made if these symptoms present ≥1 month following the traumatic event. If these symptoms are present for a duration of up to 1 month, then a diagnosis of acute stress disorder is made.

Pearl PM2336: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive


Pearl PM0378: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 


ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

* Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Depersonalization-Derealization disorder

* Dissociative Amnesia

* Trance Disorder

* Possession Trance Disorder

* Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder

* Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: 2. A schizophrenic patient responding well on haloperidol, for the past 2 years, presented with orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform, tic-like movements and possible dystonia. What is the probable diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a schizophrenic patient responding well to haloperidol for the past 2 years, presenting with orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform, tic-like movements, and possible dystonia, suggests the probable diagnosis to be Tardive dyskinesia, which is treated with Valbenazine.

Tardive dyskinesia occurs due to dopaminergic (D2) receptor supersensitivity. It presents with oro-facial dyskinesia after months to years of treatment with anti-psychotics. It can be treated with VMAT-2 inhibitors, such as Valbenazine and Deutetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option B: Acute dystonia is characterised by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back. It occurs within 1-5 days of the intake of antipsychotics

Option C: Akathisia consists of motor restlessness and occurs within 5-60 days of the intake of antipsychotics. 

Option D: Oral tremor is seen in Rabbit syndrome. Rabbit syndrome is an antipsychotic-induced rhythmic motion of the mouth/lips resembling the chewing movements of a rabbit. It occurs months to years after the intake of antipsychotics and is treated with Antiparkinsonian drugs.

Pearl PM0479: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: 3. A 68-year-old female with breast cancer with metastasis presented with breathlessness and poor health. The patient is awake and anxious. The oncology team believes that aggressive chemotherapy and radiotherapy will not be helpful. However, her daughter insists on 'trying everything', including ICU stay and mechanical ventilation. How should a doctor handle such a scenario?

choices.text: Convene a family meeting to discuss care goals and clarify the patient's preferences
Shift to ICU and start aggressive treatment
Explain no futher treatment is possible and discharge the patient to hospice
Start a placebo therapy to relieve anxiety

questions.solution:
In this case, the best way to manage the situation is to convene a family meeting to discuss care goals and clarify the patient's preferences.

Here, the patient is suffering from an advanced illness with a poor prognosis. The patient and her family are facing decisions regarding aggressive interventions such as chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and mechanical ventilation.

The recommended approach is to organize an early and structured family meeting. During this meeting, the patient's preferences should be identified, and goals should be set in collaboration with the family. This helps to reduce unrealistic expectations and may lead to shorter ICU stays when the outcome is likely to be poor. 

A 7-step protocol can be followed to decide upon the patient’s goals for care, ensuring high-quality palliative and end-of-life care:

* Collect Comprehensive Information: Make sure all medical details are complete, accurate, and clearly communicated to the patient, family, and healthcare team.

* Understand Patient and Family Hopes: Explore the hopes of the patient and family, and also identify the outcomes that are realistic and achievable.

* Present All Care Options: Share every possible intervention, explaining the benefits, limitations, and potential outcomes of each.

* Respond with Empathy: Support the patient and family emotionally as they process the situation and adjust expectations.

* Formulate a Practical Plan: Create a care plan that focuses on attaining the realistic goals aligned with the patient’s values.

* Implement the Plan: Ensure the plan is carried out consistently, coordinating with all members of the care team.

* Review and Reassess Regularly: Revisit the plan during each encounter to determine whether goals need adjustment based on the patient’s evolving condition or preferences.

questions.text: 4. A friend of Mr.K, an MBA student, describes him as being focused on rules and being very rigid. He often delays submission of assignments due to wanting them to be perfect. He also reports that Mr K keeps items that are worn out even if they don't hold any sentimental value. Mr K thinks himself to have high moral values. The friend describes that Mr K was often called 'rigid' during adolescence. When confronted with these facts, Mr K denies them outright. What is the most likely personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The most likely personality disorder is obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD), also known as Anankastic personality disorder.

According to ICD-10, the diagnostic guidelines for OCPD require the presence of at least three of eight traits or behaviours given below. These include feelings of

* Excessive doubt

* Preoccupation with details

* Perfectionism that interferes with task completion

* Excessive conscientiousness

* Excessive pedantry

* Adherence to social conventions

* Rigidity and stubbornness

* Unreasonable insistence that others submit to exactly their way of doing things

* Intrusion of insistent and unwelcome thoughts or impulses

This disorder is more often seen in males, and major depressive episodes are frequent in such patients. Psychodynamically, this disorder is believed to result from fixation at the anal sadistic phase, with reaction formation as a defense mechanism. These patients are usually treated with psychotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Dependent personality disorder requires the presence of at least three of six traits or behaviors, according to ICD-10, which include

* Allowing others to make decisions for them

* Subordination of one’s own needs to those of others and undue compliance with their wishes

* Unwillingness to make even reasonable demands on the people 

* Feeling uncomfortable or helpless when alone

* Preoccupation with fears of being abandoned by a person with whom one has a close relationship

* Difficulty in taking even the usual decisions without consultation or support from others

Option C: Narcissistic personality trait is characterized by ideas of grandiosity and an inflated sense of self-importance. The person has an attention-seeking, dramatic behavior, needs constant praise, and is unable to face criticism.

Option D: Paranoid personality disorder requires the presence of at least three out of seven traits or behaviors according to ICD-10. These traits include excessive sensitiveness, a tendency to persistently bear grudges, significant suspiciousness, a combative and tenacious sense of personal right, repeatedly doubting the partner, a tendency to experience excessive self-importance, and preoccupation with unsubstantiated conspiratorial explanations of events.

Pearl PM0379: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: 5. A 30-year-old male reports that whenever he is outside, the birds communicate to him through flapping of wings and chirping. He believes that God sends him messages through the birds, guiding him to safety. These features are characteristic of :
questions.solution:
These features are characteristic of Delusional perception.

Delusional perception means a normal perception that has been given a private and illogical meaning. It is a first-rank symptom of Schizophrenia.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

* Hallucination:

*

* First-person hallucination 

* Second-person hallucination (voices directly addressing the patient) 

* Third-person hallucination (voices speaking about the patient)

* Thought phenomenon: 

*

* Thought withdrawal

* Thought insertion

* Thought broadcasting

* Made phenomenon:

*

* Made affect

* Made impulses or drives 

* Made volitional acts 

* Delusional perception

* Somatic passivity

Other options:

Option B: A sudden delusional idea is a false, fixed belief about an idea.

Option C: Visual hallucinations is a visual perception of something that is not actually there.

Option D: Delusional memory is a false, fixed belief about a memory.

questions.text: 6. A 35-year-old man is brought to the psychiatry emergency with bizarre symptoms. A social worker reports that the man lives in a nearby village that was recently hit by an earthquake. The man appears confused and does not know how he travelled the 110 km to this city. He is unable to recollect his personal details and has no history of any substance abuse or head trauma. The family members are worried about the patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis from the given clinical scenario is dissociative fugue. 

Dissociative fugue is characterised by sudden episodes of travelling away (usually away from home). The person usually adopts a new identity during the episode, with complete amnesia for the previous life. It usually occurs due to severe stress. The termination is abrupt and is followed by amnesia for the episode, but the patient recollects the memories of earlier life. 

Other options:

Option B: Dissociative amnesia is characterised by a sudden inability to recall important personal information. The patient has amnesia related to stressful or traumatic life events. There is no evidence of an underlying medical illness.

Option C: Transient global amnesia is caused by temporary cerebral ischaemia in the distribution of the posterior cerebral circulation. It has an abrupt onset and resembles amnestic syndrome.

Option D: Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states of which only one is being manifest at a time.  Usually, one personality is not aware of the existence of the other personality. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

Pearl PM0378: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 


ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

* Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder

* Depersonalization-Derealization disorder

* Dissociative Amnesia

* Trance Disorder

* Possession Trance Disorder

* Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder

* Secondary Dissociative syndrome
